message: Today’s the first day of the 115th Congress. After electing the Speaker, the House will adopt its rules for the next 2 years.   It’s pretty amazing to me that one of the first actions the House GOP is taking in the new Congress is bringing up a rules package that would gut the independent House Office of Congressional Ethics and muzzle the American People’s Representatives with an unconstitutional, unnecessary punishment for exercising our right to free speech on the House Floor.
I voted against HR 21, a sweeping GOP “message” bill that would jeopardize public health and safety in order to address a non-existent problem.

Congress will soon consider legislation to repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, which has prohibited abusive insurance industry practices and reduced the percentage of Americans without health insurance to a record low.    It’s important to ensure that supporters of repeal understand what is at stake – like repeal of the ACA’s prohibition on benefit limits and its ban on discrimination on the basis of pre-existing conditions. Repeal of the ACA will put health insurance out of reach for many Americans, increase health care costs for others, and eliminate health care jobs.   If you and your family have benefited from the #ACA, please share your story in the comments below, and include #ACAWorks or #CoverageMatters. If you know someone who has benefited from the #ACA, please encourage them to share their story here as well.

The House Energy and Commerce Committee Democrats held their organization meeting for the new Congress this morning, and I’m very pleased to announce that I will serve as Ranking Member of the E&C Subcommittee on Communications and Technology in this Congress. I’m looking forward to working with my colleagues to protect and promote the interests of consumers and innovators, as well as to enact policies that will create jobs and foster economic growth in our country.

Representatives Evan Jenkins, Peter Welch, Tim Ryan, and I re-introduced the Assisting America’s Dislocated Miners Act, bipartisan legislation to help coal miners who have lost their jobs by getting them the training they need to get new jobs and start new careers.    I believe that the federal government has a role to play in helping Americans affected by major shifts in the economy. It should help them make a new start and get jobs where they can continue to support their families – and that’s what the Assisting America’s Dislocated Miners Act would do.

I am deeply disappointed with POTUS for his recent order banning not only all refugees from around the world, but all visitors from a number of countries. He's also harming citizens of those countries who have lived and worked in this country for years but are out of the country for work or vacation, and neighbors in our own communities who have come to make their lives and our region better. Our nation has long welcomed refugees fleeing famine and oppression. This act flies in the face of our values as Americans and our history as a refuge for those in need.
POTUS is running roughshod over American values and the Constitution - people legally in our country are being persecuted. Stop this madness.
Yes, it's a dangerous world, but let's not let our fears overwhelm our common sense.
There’s a lot going on right now, but if you haven’t enrolled in a health insurance plan for 2017, today’s the last day you can get one through www.healthcare.gov  #GetCovered!

President Trump’s latest executive actions are intended to reduce federal oversight of Wall Street banks and financial advisors. POTUS’s actions help Wall Street but increase the risk of another financial industry meltdown and reduce consumer protections for the rest of us.

You’d think that testimony from a Senate committee hearing on a cabinet nominee’s professional background could be read or discussed in the Senate chamber, especially when that nominee’s confirmation was being debated. Think again. The Senate GOP majority voted to silence Senator Elizabeth Warren for reading this testimony from Coretta Scott King about Senator Jeff Sessions, @POTUS’ nominee for Attorney General:

The American People deserve an independent investigation into President Trump’s National Security Adviser Michael Flynn’s pre-inauguration phone calls with the Russian ambassador. General Flynn had to resign; he clearly had become a potential Russian blackmail target. It’s hard to believe, however, that he would discuss the future of US sanctions without authorization - so Americans still need to know what the President and Vice President knew, and when they knew it. Flynn’s resignation is not a substitute for answers, which is why I’ve cosponsored HR 356, a bill to create a bipartisan, independent commission to investigate the extent of the Russian government’s influence on the Trump White House and presidential campaign.

Title X funding is the only source of federal funding for family planning and health care services. Each year, over 4 million Americans receive family planning and preventive care at Title X funded clinics.  6 in 10 women who rely on Title X-funded care report that it is their regular or ONLY source of health care. Yet, today, House Republicans voted to allow states to make it harder for these women to get the health care they need.    However, Title X funding isn’t just good for those in need; it’s also cost-effective. For every $1 of Title X funding spent on family planning services, an average of $7 is saved on Medicaid-related costs.    House Republicans are undermining women’s health in name of politics. It has to stop.

I love my dog Brody. On this #NationalLoveYourPetDay I wanted to left folks know that I've re-introduced the Pet Safety and Protection Act, H.R. 1141, with Representative Chris Smith (R-NJ). This bill will ensure that no research can be done with animals from so-called “Class B” dealers. These dealers pay suppliers for stolen dogs and cats from family homes, shelters, and “free to a good home” advertisements. These family pets often end up suffering from abuse, killed, or used for research. While there are only a few “Class B” dealers left, we need to end this abhorrent practice once and for all. We need to keep our pets safe and loved at home, not in labs. for more information, go to http://doyle.house.gov/press-release/congressmen-doyle-and-smith-reintroduce-legislation-protect-family-pets

Given the latest news about Sessions’ meetings with the Russian Ambassador and his failure to reveal them during the confirmation process, he needs to step aside – and there must be a completely independent investigation into all of the contacts the AG and others in the Trump campaign/Administration had with the Russians and knew about Russia’s attempts to influence our election.
Here's my opening statement at the markup of the GOP's ACA replacement bill at the House Energy and Commerce Committee this morning.

Republicans say the #ACA is a failure. It's not perfect, but they seem to have forgotten the important positive changes it made - like prohibiting insurance company discrimination against people with pre-existing conditions and annual and lifetime caps on benefits.

I'll be holding a Town Hall Meeting next Saturday, March 18, that will focus on health care and legislation Congress is considering to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (aka Obamacare). I want to let you know what's happening in Congress and hear from you about your concerns on this important issue. More details below....
The GOP bill to replace the #ACA / #Obamacare would leave most Americans worse off. But don’t take my word for it….
Big surprise.

The 2018 budget President Trump proposed yesterday calls for deep cuts in important investments like education, research, health care, and yes, even infrastructure in order to free up money for more wasteful spending on the military and a useless wall along the border. Such a budget would be devastating to Pittsburgh and other communities in western Pennsylvania, which would lose much-needed resources for education and training, health care, redevelopment, and job creation. I think that his priorities, as reflected in that budget, are deeply misguided and terribly counterproductive. I will be working in Congress to produce a budget with very different priorities – namely, investing in our people, our infrastructure, and our economy.
Don't forget - I'm holding a town hall meeting on health care and the ACA repeal bill tomorrow from 2 to 4 pm at Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall. Doors open at 1. I hope to see you there!
My town hall meeting on health care will be kicking off in an hour. For those of you who can't make it to Soldiers and Sailors Hall, we're going to try to livestream it here on facebook.

Health insurance premiums under the American Health Care Act (aka “Trumpcare”) would be 13% HIGHER on average than those under the Affordable Care Act (aka “Obamacare”), according to a Brookings Institution analysis.

The annual premium for a 64-year-old earning $26,500 a year would increase from $1,700 under the ACA to $14,600 under the GOP’s ACA Repeal bill (the American Health Care Act, aka Trumpcare), according to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office.

The Center for American Progress has calculated how many people in PA will lose their coverage under the House #ACARepeal bill. Over 1 Million in PA lose their health insurance under House GOP #ACARepeal bill, including 48,000 people in PA's 14th Congressional District.

The top doctors at Children’s Hospital and the PA Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics believe that the state’s children will suffer if the Trumpcare bill is approved and signed into law. They expressed their concerns in this op-ed published in the Post-Gazette today.
My statement opposing #TrumpCare on the floor of the House.

I’ll be on the House Floor later today leading the fight against a GOP bill to undermine Americans’ #BroadbandPrivacy. S.J.Res. 34 would overrule a recent FCC regulation protecting consumers’ privacy when they use the internet. If this bill passes, internet service providers could collect and sell data from your online communication without your permission. Moreover this legislation would prohibit the FCC from issuing ANY similar consumer protection rules in the future.

Today, the House voted to overrule the FCC and allow Internet Service Providers to collect and sell data about what you do online (and without your permission). I led the opposition to the bill (SJRes 34) on the House Floor. Here’s my opening statement.

I just started a petition urging the President to Veto S.J. Res 34, legislation that would allow Internet service providers to collect sensitive information about internet users and sell it to others – all without their consent. I don’t think the federal government should let Internet providers spy on us and sell our online data without our consent. We need to keep the FCC's Broadband Privacy Rules.

The idea of “Smart growth” can cover a lot of territory – from land use and energy to education and high-tech. The Tribune-Review published a story today about efforts in PGH to increase inclusiveness in the high-tech industry, which increases opportunity for many and produces better outcomes for firms.

I was disgusted and disappointed that President Trump signed the bill that Congressional Republicans approved to overturn the FCC regulations protecting Americans’ #BroadbandPrivacy.  This new law allows Internet Service Providers (ISPs) to collect and sell Americans’ most sensitive online data. Unfortunately, President Trump and the Republican majorities in the House and Senate are working on a long list of legislation that the majority of Americans don’t want.

I spoke out again this morning against Congressional Republicans ramming through a bill overturning FCC regulations protecting the privacy of Americans' sensitive online data. Republican majorities in the House and Senate recently approved SJRes 34, legislation overturning the FCC regulations that prohibited Internet Service Providers (ISPs) from collecting and selling customers’ sensitive online data (like Social Security Numbers, financial activities, medical information, and web-browsing histories). President Trump signed it into law on Monday.
Pittsburgh has lost a giant. Dan Rooney was a man of tremendous integrity, decency, and loyalty. I was proud to call him a friend.

President Trump’s FCC just adopted rules to make #internet service more expensive for small businesses, schools, libraries, and hospitals. Internet Service Providers (ISPs) overcharged customers by $75 billion over a recent 5-year period. The Obama Administration had been poised to adopt new rules to curb this abusive behavior, but today the Trump FCC made these services even more expensive by giving ISPs more freedom to engage in anti-competitive practices.
I spoke out earlier today against the Trump FCC Chairman's plan to dismantle the current Open Internet/Net Neutrality rules. This plan would hurt American consumers, small businesses, and innovators.

Today, the House Freedom Caucus endorsed the Republican Trumpcare bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act after it was amended to make it even worse. It would now allow states to reduce the health benefits covered by insurance policies, and it would strip away protections for people with pre-existing conditions. Once again, they would face discrimination in the insurance market and be subject to premiums and deductibles they simply cannot afford.   The amended Trumpcare bill wouldn’t address any of the other problems with the Republican “American Health Care Act” that we fought against last month. It would still gut Medicaid by over $800 billion, and it would still take health care away from 24 million Americans. Moreover, it would still provide approximately $600 billion in tax breaks to the top 1%, insurance companies, and pharmaceutical companies.   I wasn’t going to vote for the Trumpcare bill before, and I won’t be voting for it now.
Pulling out of the Paris Climate Agreement is a terrible idea. Here's why America should continue to #ActOnClimate and why @POTUS shouldn't abandon the #ParisAgreement.

President Trump’s decision to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement shows that he doesn’t understand the research on climate change and the impact it will have.   It also demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of our country’s economy in the 21st Century – not to mention the dramatic improvement in environmental quality and the economic transformation underway in Pittsburgh.   Times have changed, and so has Pittsburgh. Our air and water quality have improved dramatically, and Pittsburgh is becoming a leader in carbon-free energy sources and energy efficiency technologies. Pittsburgh is adapting to climate realities – and positioning our industries to provide good jobs to Pittsburghers by fighting the very real challenge of climate change.   Today’s reversal on the Paris Agreement is foolhardy and incredibly disappointing. President Trump clearly doesn’t understand the Paris treaty – and he certainly doesn’t understand my district. By withdrawing from this non-binding agreement, we’re giving up our leadership on the issue and we won’t even have a seat at the table. I will continue to fight for policies that address climate change by creating good jobs for Pittsburghers.

I voted against HR 10, the "Financial CHOICE Act." This Republican bill to repeal the 2010 #DoddFrank #WallStReform law would undermine consumer and investor protections. It would also increase the risk of another financial meltdown like the one in 2008 – and eliminate some of the tools regulators would need to fix it. HR 10 should be called the #WrongChoiceAct.
I joined other @EnergyCommerce Democrats in urging @HouseCommerce Republicans to hold bipartisan hearings with us on reducing prescription drug costs:
Nice to see you in Pittsburgh again, Lord Stanley! Back to Back Stanley Cup Champs!!

Today, Senate Republicans released their plan to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. It’s not that different from the Trumpcare bill passed by the House last month. Both would kick millions of vulnerable Americans off Medicaid, force millions of other Americans to pay more money for less coverage, and give $600 billion in tax breaks to corporations and the wealthy. The article below describes the bill in greater detail. The House and Senate Trumpcare bills are worse for most Americans than current law. Republicans should stop trying to sabotage and repeal the Affordable Care Act – and work with Democrats to improve it instead.

The CBO’s analysis of the Senate GOP’s so-called “Better Care Reconciliation Act” confirms what we all suspected – this legislation would cut taxes for corporations and the wealthy by $700 billion, and would cut health care for low- and middle-income households to pay for it. It’s not much different that the American Health Care Act passed by House Republicans last month.   CBO estimates that more than 22 million Americans would lose health care coverage under this bill - but this bill would affect ALL Americans – not just those on Medicaid and in the ACA health insurance exchanges. Millions of others would end up paying more for insurance that covers less.    Once again, we could all be at the mercy of insurance companies and their abusive practices that the Affordable Care Act prohibited – like annual and lifetime benefit caps and discrimination against people with pre-existing conditions.   Once again, Americans could go broke paying for things like mental health care, maternity care, and prescription drugs.   It’s obvious that this bill was drafted with the goal of cutting taxes for corporations and the wealthy, not improving health care for most Americans. Senator McConnell ought to throw this bill in the trash and start over – this time with an open and transparent bipartisan process and the goal of improving and strengthening the existing Affordable Care Act. That’s something I have always stood ready to do.
At noon, I'll be joining other US Representatives and Senators at a press conference on #NetNeutrality Watch live:
I'll be hosting this discussion on Net Neutrality today between 2 and 3 PM - if the House voting schedule permits!

I am participating in the Net Neutrality National Day of Action today.  I have been strong advocate for a free and open Internet and I have long fought to put in place rules to protect consumers and small businesses.  These rules are essential to protecting the Internet and the enormous engine of growth and opportunity it has become.   More than that, the Internet has become the medium through which we communicate with friends, family, and express ourselves as individuals and citizens of this country.  Net Neutrality is more than an economic issue, it is an issue of our freedom to communicate and express ourselves and our rights under the law to do so.  Many have said that this is the First Amendment right of the 21st Century, and I agree.   An Open Internet is essential to fostering innovation, promoting public discourse, protecting small businesses, and preserving consumers’ ability to access online content.  The current Net Neutrality rules protect and preserve the Open Internet as a platform for competition, innovation, and free speech. They allow the growth of new and improved internet services and applications that would never get off the ground without a level playing field. These strong, enforceable rules, which have stood up to court challenge, prohibit the blocking or throttling of online content – and they prevent carriers from establishing fast lanes or paid prioritization.  The American People have spoken out loud and clear in support of Net Neutrality - more than 6.5 million people have filed comments with the FCC so far this year. They support the current Net Neutrality rules, which protect consumers, small businesses, and edge providers looking to provide innovative and competitive new services. They deserve to have their views respected by the federal government. The current Net Neutrality rules preserve a free and open internet, which promotes innovation, competition, greater economic growth, and free speech while protecting consumers and small businesses. I believe the FCC should listen to the millions of Americans who’ve filed comments urging the Commission to preserve its current Open Internet rules.
I'm about to participate in a press conference to support the current Net Neutrality rules.
Livestreamed discussion about Net Neutrality starting at 1:30.

I just met with Team Hope – a group of young Syrian refugees who participated in the FIRST Global Challenge, an international robotics competition held this week in DC. What remarkable young people!

I am deeply disappointed in the President’s decision to end Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals.    I believe that DACA was a reasonable and compassionate way to deal with undocumented young people who came to this country as children and grew up here. They did nothing wrong, and many of them know no other home.    The President’s action today is extremely reckless and puts hundreds of thousands of people at risk. This action will have a profoundly negative effect on these young people’s lives, our communities, and the economy.     I will certainly do all that I can to protect DACA and the DREAMers who call our country home. Congress should pass the Dream Act immediately.

I just voted against HR 3354, a GOP bill to cut essential federal investments in education, health, research, and infrastructure.

Just when you thought that GOP attempts to take health insurance away from millions of Americans - and raise health care costs and reduce health insurance coverage for millions more - were over, the Senate GOP takes one more stab at it:

The Graham-Cassidy bill is the worst version of Trumpcare yet, but the GOP plans to ram it through Congress. NO to this terrible bill. Graham-Cassidy would allow states to eliminate essential health benefits and protections for pre-existing conditions, as well as the Affordable Care Act's ban on annual and lifetime limits on how much health care insurance companies will pay for policy-holders' medical care. This is a terrible bill.

A new study by the Kaiser Family Foundation estimates that PA would lose $12 Billion between 2020 and 2026 - and more than $10 billion annually after 2026 under Graham-Cassidy, the latest Trumpcare bill.

Congress is sponsoring a competition for apps written by K-12 students – the Congressional App Challenge. Students must register and submit their app by November 1, 2017. For more information, visit my website.

With his Executive Order yesterday and his announcement last night, President Trump has taken several major steps to undermine the Affordable Care Act and make health care more expensive – and in some cases unaffordable – for millions of Americans.    I’m outraged and disgusted that anyone would stoop so low.    I will continue to do everything in my power to prevent President Trump from taking affordable health care away millions of Americans.

I am extremely disappointed in President Trump’s decision to declare that Iran is not in compliance with the JCPOA (Iran Nuclear Deal). Under law, the President is required to provide Congress with evidence that Iran is non-compliant. No such evidence has been provided to Congress to-date.    This decision by the President goes against the advice of experts around the world and within his own Cabinet, and is intended only to fulfill an unwise campaign promise; this should not be the way that our foreign affairs are conducted.    By declaring that Iran is no longer in compliance, Congress now has 60 days to decide whether to re-impose sanctions that were suspended under the deal. I hope that Congress will act wisely, and not re-impose sanctions without cause.    Regardless, I am concerned that today’s decision will have grave effects beyond sanctions. Our allies around the world have shown no signs of ending the agreement, making any attempt to ‘tear up the deal’ or impose sanctions meaningless. By walking away from this agreement, President Trump may once again reduce America’s credibility with our allies, embolden Iran, hurt America’s economy, and threaten our national security. It also weakens  our position to try and diplomatically defuse the growing crisis in North Korea.   I had hoped that President Trump would not gamble so recklessly with America’s foreign policy, but once again I am disappointed.

The House is scheduled to vote this week on the Senate GOP budget which would cut billions of dollars from Medicare, Medicaid, SSI, and other essential government programs in order to pay for a massive tax cut for corporations and the wealthiest Americans. 80 percent of the tax cuts in the House-Senate-POTUS tax “reform” framework would go to the wealthiest 1 percent – Americans with incomes of more than $900,000 a year.

GOP Budget calls for massive tax cuts for Americans with incomes of more than $900,000 – while households with incomes of $75,000 or less would receive tax cuts averaging less than $200 – and millions of middle-class households would actually see their TAXES INCREASE! Moreover, the GOP budget calls for billions of dollars in cuts in programs that help most Americans – like Medicare, Medicaid, and very likely education, medical research, infrastructure investment, and law enforcement, just to name a few....

You may be eligible to buy affordable health insurance through healthcare.gov.   OPEN ENROLLMENT SEASON FOR 2018 STARTS TODAY.   Open Enrollment this year runs from November 1st through December 15th.   This is your chance to get health insurance that works well for you and your family. You can find plans with no-cost preventive care — like flu shots and mammograms — and you may be eligible for assistance with paying your premium.   There are a number of places you can go — and people you can talk to — if you have questions or you need help signing up. That help’s completely free. You can call 1-800-318-2596 or go online to localhelp.healthcare.gov.   Don’t miss this opportunity to get affordable, high-quality health insurance. The December 15th deadline is fast-approaching, so be sure to visit healthcare.gov for more information.   #GetCovered!

The tax bill the House is expected to consider next week would eliminate the deduction for medical expenses. Under current law, you can deduct medical expenses in excess of 7.5 percent of of your income. It provides important tax relief for individuals and households with serious health problems that require expensive care. Have any of you in PA’s 14th Congressional District used that deduction?  I’d like to hear about it.
“Senate bill would raise taxes on millions of middle-class families ... disproportionately benefit high earners and corporations.”

The National Committee to Preserve Social Security and Medicare (NCPSSM) opposes the passage of HR 1, the GOP tax bill, because it will cut Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. I oppose HR 1 for that reason, too – along with a lot of other reasons! It’s a terrible bill, and it won't hurt just older Americans.... Click below to read their letter.

I oppose HR 1, the GOP tax bill, and I spoke against it on the House Floor during the debate. This bill‘s supporters promise big tax cuts for the Middle Class – but it actually raises taxes on millions of Middle-Class households and does very little for the rest, while targeting most of its cuts taxes to corporations and the rich. On top of that, it would jack up future deficits and the national debt by trillions of dollars, increasing the pressure for additional cuts in essential programs like Medicare and Medicaid. It really is a massive #GOPTaxScam.
I voted against this back-loaded attack on the Middle Class, and I will continue to fight for tax reform that benefits the hard-working Americans who need help the most.

Chairman Pai has once again jammed a profoundly anti-consumer agenda through the FCC.  In gutting the FCC’s media ownership rules, the Commission has recklessly promoted the unhealthy consolidation of media ownership and continued paving the way for the Sinclair merger.  In addition, the Commission kneecapped the Lifeline program, which could well take low-income phone and internet access away from children, veterans, and the disabled.  The Commission also dumped a risky new broadcast TV standard on the American people. The new standard won’t work on today’s televisions – and could leave consumers without any access to broadcast TV.  Each of these decisions is terrible in its own right, but they are all part of the Chairman’s radical anti-consumer, anti-competitive agenda.

Our veterans risked their lives for this nation. Making sure they have a home should be one of the ways we demonstrate our appreciation for their service.   The Trump Administration’s decision to cut a critical $460 million program which helps homeless vets is disgraceful. On December 1, the Department of Veterans Affairs announced its decision to cut $265 million from this program immediately and to divert $195 million more under the 2018 budget. While it claims it will redistribute these funds to VA facilities across the country that deal with homelessness, there's no requirement  that they use the money to help homeless vets. I’d rather see the money stay in the program that’s focused on homeless veterans.   While we have made progress in housing our veterans, there are still 40,000 homeless veterans today who need help. We should build on the progress we’ve made and continue to fulfill our obligation to do right by these honorable Americans. I am committed to standing by these men and women and fighting the Administration’s recent announcement.

Because of the backlash from Americans across the country, the VA has reversed its decision to cut funding to help homeless vets. The VA says it will be reviewing the decision, but we’d better stay vigilant to make sure our veterans are taken care of!
I’ll be starting a @Reddit AMA on #NetNeutrality today at 3 PM EST.

Today, amid all the noise, all the tweets, all the Facebook posts, TV shows, Christmas shopping, and laundry, I am asking you to pause and join me in remembering the 26 lives lost five years ago when a man entered Sandy Hook Elementary School and murdered 20 innocent children and 6 brave teachers.    Since that day, the death toll has continued to increase – while Congress has yet to pass any meaningful legislation to stop the rising tide of gun violence in our country.   Our failure to do anything continues to haunt me, and will haunt this Congress until we do our job.    Those twenty children and their teachers will always remain a part of our national memory. We will never forget them, and today we will grieve for them. But every day, we must work to end the senseless loss of innocent lives to gun violence.    Today, I join over 1.5 million other Americans in making the Sandy Hook Promise to keep our kids safe.

Now that the FCC has voted to kill Net Neutrality, putting the Internet as we know it at risk, I will be introducing legislation to overturn today’s order, restore Net Neutrality, and protect a free and open Internet.

I'm proud to introduce bipartisan legislation with fellow Pennsylvanian and E&C member Rep. Ryan Costello to encourage investment in energy storage technologies. We need these technologies to facilitate increased adoption of renewable energy, improve the resilience and security of the our electric grid, and lower the cost of energy bills.

I voted against the Republican bill cutting more than a trillion dollars in taxes for corporations and the rich – and putting the burden of paying for it on the middle class, the poor, and our grandchildren.  Under the GOP tax bill, more than 80 percent of the cuts will go to households making more than $5 million a year. That’s no Middle Class tax cut.  But there are many other reasons behind my vote against this misguided bill: •it will actually raise taxes on most Middle Class households after a few short years, with more than half of all taxpayers - 86 million households - paying more; •it won’t raise wages;  •it gives a new tax break to corporations for shipping US jobs overseas;  •it will cause a $25 billion cut in Medicare next year; and •it will cause federal budget deficits to explode, increasing the national debt by more than $1.5 trillion.   Enactment of the Republican tax bill will leave most households worse off in the long run. Their tax cuts will be replaced with tax increases, and Republicans plan to use the increased national debt as justification to cut programs like Medicare and Medicaid that most Americans rely on.   Moreover, rather than providing the greatest tax relief to families who need it the most – who will pump that money right back into the economy – the GOP tax bill provides the lion’s share of its tax cuts to corporations and the households that are the most well off.   This tax bill is a scam perpetrated on the American People by Republicans in Congress and the White House. When the American People discover what this bill really does, they will hold those who are responsible for it accountable.  I will continue to work in Congress to curb these unsustainable giveaways to corporations and the rich – and to redirect federal resources to the millions of families who are struggling to get by. They’re the ones who need and deserve tax relief and adequately funded federal programs like Medicare and Medicaid.

US Representative Mike Doyle will be holding a town hall meeting focused on health care and legislation to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. The meeting will take place March 18 from 2 to 4 pm at Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall, 4141 Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213
